author: trent_vanepps
content:
incredible. i'd love to see the methodology behind this

https://twitter.com/christine_dkim/status/1461346245004255283?s=20

author: Deleted User
content: They looked at people who offer for example 300 basefee, but ended up getting included for 150, saving them 150 in basefee, and voila, fee savings. But would they have bid 300 gwei in the first place if EIP1559 didnt exist?

author: trent_vanepps
content: it's not a perfect measure, no

author: Deleted User
content: true. but im of the opinion that EIP1559 leads to higher fees because an algorithm will never be as effecient as a free floating price, and the functionality that allows people to just put in a high bid and get some of it back encourages people to be more likely to overbid.

author: Deleted User
content: in order to confirm the theory you would need to be able to objectively measure demand for transactions and compare it with fees pre and post EIP1559

author: Deleted User
content: which is not possible i think

author: Deleted User
content:
"efficient as free floating price"
=> free floating price isn't efficient at all. People don't know what to bid, as the volatility is high, so they overbid, and then they DON'T get refunded.

"encourages people to be more likely to overbid"
=> so what? They are refunded anyway, so that the price they pay is fair.
